email.body:
Hello, I'm trying to get php-gtk working on a debian linux system and am having some trouble. Being optimistic, I coped php_gtk_new.m4 to php_gtk.m4 and buildconf then completed successfully in spite of about 100 "underquoted definition of" warning messages. Then I did ./configure and that completed also. These errors are, I believe, coming from the Defs_Parser constructor (in generator/scheme.php) which is being called from generator/generator.php, which is being executed directly from the Makefiles in many places with "--" as the first argument. email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] php_win.exe crashes when in a directory with spaces
email.body:
Hi folks,
When working on a new WinBinder demo (http://winbinder.sourceforge.net/), I found out that php_win.exe for PHP 4 (from PHP-GTK) crashes when called from a folder with spaces. For example, c:\PHP\myapp\php_win.exe runs fine, but c:\Program Files\myapp\php_win.exe consistently crashes. This can be a problem for Windows users since the applications path typically has a space.
More specifically, php.exe (AppVer: 4.3.9.9) crashes php4ts.dll at offset 000BB8E4 with code 0xC0000005 (EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION). I'm using the files from php-gtk-1.0.1a-win32.zip.
Interestingly, php.exe always runs perfectly, even on a directory with spaces (although it opens a DOS box, of course). Also, PHP 5 does not have this problem -- but in this case I'm using the file php-win.exe and the others that come with it.
Does anybody knows how to find (or build) a version of php_win.exe that won't crash in this situation?
Many thanks in advance,
------------------- Rubem Pechansky

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Gtk_MessageBox
email.body:
Hi
Some might know that there are several MessageBox classes for php-gtk flouncing around the web. I think mine was the first one, Alan adopted it for one of his projects, Nathan did another one...
I think it's time to get a PEAR msgbox, and I'm currently collecting ideas for the class - Must display text, title and icon :) - Enable different buttons, with some standard ones being hardcoded (Ok, Yes/No, Yes/No/Cancel, Abort/Retry/Ignore, ....) but keep the option to define own ones - Default selected button - Standard icons should be provided: Question, Information, Error, Warning - A "don't ask/show this any more" checkbox would be nice - One-line call: No need to instantiate something, just call "$nAnswer = Gtk_MessageBox( 'hello', 'test);"
Now the things I'm pondering with: - The java message box classes have the option for a text entry box (JOptionPane.showInputDialog). Would this fit in the class, or should that be a different one? - RTL/LTR support (icon on the left or right side), is there a setting in a standard location which could be read easily (php config or so) - Icons: Have four icons vs. Have four icons for every operating system (windows icons are very different from gtk/kde ones). What to implement? - Make text alignment options sense? (left/center/right) - How to pass the parameters? In VC++, you have three params: Text, title and options with "options" being a sum of options (int). My current implementation uses this, but somebody indicated some years ago that that's too C'ish. But how to pass a number of parameters in a really easy way? - How to return the "don't ask/show this any more" setting - the pressed button has to be returned as well. Array makes no sense, as one had to expect an array always - equals if the "don't ask" feature is used. It would be possible to return an int if no "don't ask" is used, and an array with "button" and "dontask" values if it's used. Is that good style? Don't really think so. - Are int values ok for standard button returns? My current class uses constants like IDYES, IDNO and IDCANCEL. - If text input is ok, how to pass the inputted text back? array? (selected button has to be returned as well) - Is it allowed in PEAR to have functions outside a class?
I think Abort/retry/ignore can be left out, it's a relict from my Visual C++ times...
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Juli - Tränenschwer

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Constructor semantics
email.body:
Hi gang,
I am at point in working on generator where we need to figure out how constructors should function. I have 2 issues to discuss.
Gtk2 allows for a property based constructor invocation, something like:
GtkAlignment *align = (GtkAlignment *)g_object_newv(GTK_TYPE_ALIGNMENT, "xalign", 1.0, "yalign", 0.0, "xscale", 0.5, NULL);
The old style was:
GtkAlignment *align = gtk_alignment_new(1.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0);
PyGtk has utilized this to make generation of constructors easier. The properties are defined in the .defs file, the generator parses them and generates property based constructor that can be invoked as:
align = gtk.GtkAlign(xalign = 1.0, yalign = 0.0, xscale = 0.5)
or something like that.
The old style of constructors is not deprecated, so it's still possible to invoke it as:
align = gtk.GtkAlign(1.0, 0.0, 0.5);
So, in our case, should we just stick with how PHP-GTK1 constructors worked or should we try to allow pseudo-keyword invokation?
$align = new GtkAlignment(array('xalign' => 1.0, 'yalign' => 0.0, 'xscale' => 0.5));
The second question is what should we do if constructor encounters an error. In PHP-GTK 1 we invalidated $this variable (setting it to NULL), but in PHP-GTK 2 I am tempted to raise an exception.
-Andrei

I think that depends on how long PHP-Gtk 1.x will still be used. I think if there is a valid reason to use 1.x after the release of 2.x then sure it makes sense because people using the 1.x branch won't have this functionality. If there isn't a valid reason to use it after 2.x has been released, then it depends on how long it will take to get to a stable 2.x release. I think Anrdei said on IRC the other day that he expects a first release of 2.x in two to three months. A PEAR class takes at least 2 weeks to get accepted after the code is written so your class wouldn't be out there very long before it gets made obsolete by 2.0.
I think your idea is great but the timing is off just a little. I don't know of any reason to keep using 1.x after the release of 2.0 and I think 2.0 will come out too soon for your class to be widely used and excepted. I do think that this would make a great article/tutorial on extending PHP-Gtk for code reusability though. email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-Gtk2 installer / extension problem
email.body:
Hi
I know there is still much time, but today I thought about an installer for PHP-Gtk2, at least for windows.
People should have the possibility to install php-gtk in a really easy way by clicking on an .exe, pointint to some "next" buttons and all works. This can be done very easily with the NSIS installer, as it is scriptable - just the compilation has to be done on a windows machine.
When having an installer, I think the chance is there to associate the php-gtk files with the installed php5.exe. This would ensure that the "install&run" experience is perfect - click on a php-gtk application, and its window pops up. Now there is the question with the right file extension. I know we had the discussion two years ago, but there was no agreement among the people, and we didn't get a result. The best extension - IMHO - was ".phpw", the "windowed php application". Other suggestions were to have a context menu entry for opening the whole thing in the console, but as an addition to the console-less default.
Your thoughts?

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] trouble compiling php-gtk on debian linux system
email.body:
Hi Nate,
I just ran into the same problem trying to install this morning on Fedora 2. The problem is that generator/scheme.php is trying to load a file that doesn't exist. Because the file doesn't exist a php error message gets written into the ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.c file. That's what causes all sorts of syntax errors.
It looks like the CVS version has been updated so you may want to try that. But here is what I did:
Edit generator/scheme.php: line 110 change from: $this->parse_tree = parse(fopen($defs_file, 'r')); to: $this->parse_tree = parse(@fopen($defs_file, 'r')); (optionally and 'the right way' is to do a check like if (is_readable($defs_file)) ...)
Then I did a make clean. Then I had to remove ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.c Then start over with ./buildconf etc...
My steps may not have been the most efficient way to go about it but it worked for me.
Scott Mattocks

Scott Mattocks wrote:
> Hi Nate, > > I just ran into the same problem trying to install this morning on > Fedora 2. The problem is that generator/scheme.php is trying to load a > file that doesn't exist. Because the file doesn't exist a php error > message gets written into the ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.c file. That's what > causes all sorts of syntax errors. > > It looks like the CVS version has been updated so you may want to try > that. But here is what I did: > > Edit generator/scheme.php: line 110 > change from: > $this->parse_tree = parse(fopen($defs_file, 'r')); > to: > $this->parse_tree = parse(@fopen($defs_file, 'r')); > (optionally and 'the right way' is to do a check like if > (is_readable($defs_file)) ...) > > Then I did a make clean. > Then I had to remove ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.c > Then start over with ./buildconf etc... > > My steps may not have been the most efficient way to go about it but > it worked for me. > > Scott Mattocks >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums/flags as objects?
email.body:
I have just discovered that it is possible to register object constants. This raises interesting possibilities. In PHP-GTK 1, the various enums/flags are simply integers, so it is hard sometimes to figure out what 0 or 2 means when trying to debug the applications. With the object approach, each enum could be an object wrapper, that knows how to compare itself, output its string representation, etc. The downside is that objects take more memory, obviously.
Do you think wrapping enums/flags as objects has advantages? PyGtk 2.3.x seems to do it this way.
-Andrei

I disagree about the vote in this case. We are likely to get lots of conflicting opinions which will not help matters, but will just delay the development. In my personal, somewhat strong, opinion the combination of Gtk2 + PHP5 fully justifies any sort of BC breakage that we may need. After all, PHP-GTK 1 was written without any sort of action, plan, rhyme or reason. I just invented things as I went along, and I would be loathe to have to preserve something stupid if we can make it much better. As Frank said, people are free to use PHP-GTK 1 + PHP 4 if they feel so. Of course there will be work in rewriting the apps if people want to switch to PHP-GTK 2, but most likely they would be rewriting them anyway, to take advantage of PHP 5's object-oriented features.

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] gladexml::signal_autoconnect parameter
email.body:
Christian Weiske wrote:
> While documenting the glade extension I stumbled over the > signal_autoconnect function. > > It does not require but accept one parameter of type array. > As I didn't find any other documentation and didn't get smart of the > php-gtk sources: > > Could somebody (Andrei?) explain the meaning of this array?
Basically it works this warning: I haven't used this stuff for years!):
As usual you build your GUI in glade and define some handlers for signals, etc. Then \ you load the glade file into PHP-GTK:
$gx = &new GladeXML( GLADE_XML_GUI_FILE))
and you've also prepared all kinds of functions (== handlers) you already defined in \ the glade file. Now it's time to map the handlers from the glade file to your actualy \ PHP application functions/methods.
This is were signal_autoconnect comes into play. Basically, the parameter is a hash \ in the form of name_of_handler_from_glade_file => which_php_function_to_call. In real \ source code, this could look like this:
@$gx->signal_autoconnect( array( // main window 'on_menu_file_quit_activate' => array( array( &$this, 'shutdown')), 'on_mainWindow_destroy' => array( array( &$this, 'shutdown')), 'on_textSqlIn_key_press_event' => array( array( &$this, 'doQuery')),
// database manager window 'on_menu_manage_activate' => array( array( &$this->managerGui, \ 'show')), 'on_windowManageDatabases_delete_event' => array( array( \ &$this->managerGui, 'hide')), 'on_buttonAdd_clicked' => array( \ array( &$this->managerGui, 'newConnection')), 'on_buttonApply_clicked' \ => array( array( &$this->managerGui, 'applyChanges')), \ 'on_listConnections_select_row' => array( array( &$this->managerGui, \ 'configuredConnectionSelected')), 'on_buttonDelete_clicked' => array( \ array( &$this->managerGui, 'deleteConnection')), 'on_buttonConnect_clicked' \ => array( array( &$this->notebook, 'addConnection')), \ 'on_statusList_button_press_event' => array( array( &$this->notebook, \ 'selectRow')), 'on_windowAbout_delete_event' => array( array( \ &$this->aboutDialog, 'hide')), 'on_menu_help_about_activate' => array( \ array( &$this->aboutDialog, 'show')), \ 'on_windowManageDatabases_key_press_event'=>array( array( &$this->managerGui, \ 'processKeyboardEvents')), 'on_connectionNotebook_switch_page' => array( array( \ &$this->notebookGui, 'watchPageSwitch')) ));
"on_menu_file_quit_activate", "on_mainWindow_destroy", etc. are all define in the \ glade XML file. Here's a short snip from the glade generated XML file:
<widget> <class>GtkMenuItem</class> <name>menu_file_quit</name> <accelerator> <modifiers>GDK_CONTROL_MASK</modifiers> <key>GDK_q</key> <signal>activate</signal> </accelerator> <signal> <name>activate</name> <handler>on_menu_file_quit_activate</handler> <last_modification_time>Sun, 08 Apr 2001 22:38:29 \ GMT</last_modification_time> </signal> <label>Quit</label> <right_justify>False</right_justify> </widget> </widget>
As you can see, the signal activate is defined to call the handler \ on_menu_file_quit_activate, which is mapped via signal_autoconnect() to the right PHP \ handler.
I think, if your PHP functions are named exactly the way they are named in the glade \ XML file, you don't have to use the array. However, in bigger applications (which \ these snipplets are from, although it never grew over a certain size) you don't want \ to have zillions of global functions; thus you remap them to your dedicated \ objects/methods as you can see in the example above.
I do not remember, why the right part of the hash is an array itself. The syntax is:
signal_autoconnect( array( 'glade_handler' => array('php_function_to_call'), ));
When you connect to objects, you need to use the array syntax:
signal_autoconnect( array( 'glade_hjandler' => array( array(&$object, 'method') ) ));
However, as stated, I don't remmeber why it's an array at all; maybe it's possible to \ have multitple handlers called.
Attached is an small writing about php-gtk from that time, maybe it's of value to you \ (I've renamed the HTML file to txt in the hope it won't get stripped); it contains \ signal_autoconnect() examples too.
HTH, sincerly,
- Markus

email.body:
On 17 juil. 04, at 05:47, Alan Knowles wrote:
> >>> I would like to make a few comments and raise a few questions >>> PHP is a software enabling access to a function reference base base >>> organised by groups. >>> Ex. Database : MySQL, PgSQL, Oracle >>> As far as I know there is no stand alone php mysql project >>> Why PHP GTK would be one ? > Probably due to the scale of the project (mysql has ~20 functions, > gtk has > 900) > > Merging that kind of documentation into the main manual would not be a > good idea.. >
The Idea is not to port every GTK functions because we will get problems with WinUI and all other User interface references. I said that it will be nice to make wrappers for all UI. The question is : What need a php developper to build him local application ?
I do a list of needs. And i found at the moment these few exemple : Make window. Change window property Input, checkbox, listbox and datagrid. Rendering interface for OpenGL & DirectX (visual & virtual) etc...
Concerning the documentation, no problem, it's very easy to make documentation of wrappers than 900 GTK functions :)
Let me finish my job on this subject i will present the project php-ui in few days to Steph and Andreis.
-mike

Scott, congratulations! I think you found a PHP-GTK bug.
attributes.event_mask = gtk_widget_get_events (widget); attributes.event_mask |= (GDK_EXPOSURE_MASK | GDK_BUTTON_PRESS_MASK | GDK_BUTTON_RELEASE_MASK | GDK_BUTTON1_MOTION_MASK | GDK_BUTTON3_MOTION_MASK | GDK_POINTER_MOTION_HINT_MASK | GDK_POINTER_MOTION_MASK | GDK_ENTER_NOTIFY_MASK | GDK_LEAVE_NOTIFY_MASK); (from gtkentry.c, around line 1000 in my - admittedly GTK 2 - copy)
- that's where the event_masks for the widgets are originally set. So there's your list for GtkEntry, at least..
The notes for gtk_widget_get_events itself say: * gtk_widget_get_events: * @widget: a #GtkWidget * * Returns the event mask for the widget (a bitfield containing flags * from the #GdkEventMask enumeration). These are the events that the widget * will receive.
All I get here from var_dump($widget->get_events()); is int[0].
You can either trawl through GTK src looking for attributes.event_mask, or you could steal the bit of PHP-GTK code from the signals/events chapter in the manual and play with the widgets to see what you get. I don't know if there's any point in putting in a bug report at this stage, everyone's busy with PHP 5 development and will then be straight onto PHP-GTK 2.. but copying this to the dev list anyway so everyone knows it's there.
Sorry, - Steph

Embedding it into any of the php binaries (php.exe or php-win.exe) wold not do you any good. You are not using any of these files to edit the content of the php scripts. The OS will not execute the associated executable to figure out which icon to show with a script file. Ok. So here is what I have for December news:
Ben mentioned an article about PHP-Gtk usage in companies. It looks like it didn't make it though.
Madeline asked to point out the php-gtk-general thread about PHP-Gtk use in companies.
Nate pointed out that Roadsend can now compile PHP-Gtk apps to run without an installed version of PHP-Gtk on a user's computer.
I got an email today saying that the International PHP Confernce has put out a call for papers and one of the topics they are looking for is PHP-Gtk.
We also have a new Russian version of the docs. (The docs page needs to be updated though.)
Combining all of this glorious news I have come up with the following news item. Please feel free to make comments, suggestions, point out other items or completely rewrite it. Links need to be added but I figured the first version can leave them out for readability's sake.
PHP-Gtk in business There has been a lot of discusson lately about the role PHP-Gtk can and is playing in the business world. Several people have commented on the php-gtk-general mailing list about how they have developed secure, cross-platform applications for use in business with PHP-Gtk. Using tools such as Roadsend's PHP Compiler, developers are able to create and distribute PHP-Gtk applications that don't require the user to have a working installation first.
On the international level, PHP-Gtk documentation is now available in Russian thanks to the work of Andrew Krasnyansky. Also, the organizers of the International PHP Conference have put out a call for papers. One of the requested topics is PHP-Gtk.
